Three years ago, the Marvel Cinematic Universe unexpectedly struck gold with Guardians Of The Galaxy. This movie was based on a comic that the vast majority of people would never have heard of, let alone read. But it hit just the tone that audiences were looking for, it was colourful, and it introduced new worlds to the franchise audiences loved so much. This genuinely funny, family-friendly blockbuster movie was so successful that movies are still attempting to recreate its look and feel. So, of course, it spawned a sequel.<p><br></p><p><br></p><p>The plot of Guardians Of The Galaxy Vol. 2 is difficult to discuss properly without spoilers. While I've tried to keep the following description as spoiler-free as possible, everyone has a different idea of spoilers, so beware.</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p style="background-repeat: no-repeat; background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png;base64,&quot;); background-position: 672px 0px;">On the run from a client they've offended, the Guardians run into Star-Lord's biological father, Ego. After Rocket and Baby Groot are taken by Yondu (who had been hired to capture the Guardians but could not turn Quill in), Ego takes the others to the planet he himself created.</p><p style="background-repeat: no-repeat; background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png;base64,&quot;); background-position: 672px 0px;"><br></p><p style="background-repeat: no-repeat; background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png;base64,&quot;); background-position: 672px 0px;"><br></p><p style="background-repeat: no-repeat; background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png;base64,&quot;); background-position: 672px 0px;">After this, some time is given for sub-plots to unfold - one of Yondu's crew leads a mutiny and locks Yondu up with Rocket; Nebula (who was imprisoned by the Guardians but ended up involved in the mutiny) leaves to fight Gamora; Peter bonds with Ego and learns more about who both of them are. This gives time for each of these duos to bond and for their characters to develop, which is something that this movie needed. The Avengers works because each major player had their own movie, but Guardians works because they spend such a huge portion of their films fleshing out the characters through their friendships and rivalries.</p><p style="background-repeat: no-repeat; background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png;base64,&quot;); background-position: 672px 0px;"><br></p><p style="background-repeat: no-repeat; background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png;base64,&quot;); background-position: 672px 0px;"><br></p><p style="background-repeat: no-repeat; background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png;base64,&quot;); background-position: 672px 0px;">In fact, it's this attention to the subplots and previously neglected characters that change the pace of this movie compared to the rest of the MCU. It isn't until the last 40 minutes of the movie that the main plot begins to unfold and the villain is introduced. The events that lead up to the climax almost feel rushed or forced, but it's forgivable considering the time is well spent elsewhere, and that this movie features the most well-written villain in the MCU since the Jessica Jones series.</p><p style="background-repeat: no-repeat; background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png;base64,&quot;); background-position: 672px 0px;"><br></p><p style="background-repeat: no-repeat; background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png;base64,&quot;); background-position: 672px 0px;"><br></p><p style="background-repeat: no-repeat; background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png;base64,&quot;); background-position: 672px 0px;"><span style="color: rgb(51, 51, 51);">Excellent performances from Rooker (Yondu) and Gillan (Nebula), whose characters really came into their own in this sequel after the first movie used them as context for the heroes and not much else. The only characters that were properly neglected in this film were Drax and new girl Mantis, as their motivations and personalities were left to rot in favour of sometimes-cheap comic relief.</span><br></p><p style="background-repeat: no-repeat; background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png;base64,&quot;); background-position: 672px 0px;"><span style="color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"><br></span></p><p style="background-repeat: no-repeat; background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png;base64,&quot;); background-position: 672px 0px;"><span style="color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"><br></span></p><p style="background-repeat: no-repeat; background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png;base64,&quot;); background-position: 672px 0px;"><span style="background-repeat: no-repeat; background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png;base64,&quot;); background-position: 672px 0px;">There is so much more to unpack in this movie, such as the film's easter egg-riddled credits scenes (of which there were FIVE), the incredible and unexpected cameo towards the end, and the gorgeous work by the effects and makeup teams. However, I recommend that you watch it for yourself, as I would easily call this one of the best Marvel movies.</span></p>
